newsitem.title: USA: Mississippi high court hears tobacco case.
newsitem.headline: Mississippi high court hears tobacco case.

text.p: Mississippi's highest court heard arguments on Wednesday in a power struggle between the state attorney general and Gov. Kirk Fordice over authority to sue the tobacco industry.

Fordice, a Republican, filed suit to stop the state Attorney General Mike Moore, a Democrat, from moving against the tobacco companies, one of more than a dozen actions taken by state governments to try and recover Medicaid payments to sick smokers.
The court gave no indication of how soon it might issue a ruling.

Lawyers for the governor told the Mississippi Supreme Court that state laws give the Republican governor sole authority to decide whether to file a lawsuit for recovery of Medicaid payments to sick smokers. The governor is head of the state's division of Medicaid.
But Moore said the state supreme court's own rulings over the decades have placed the authority to decide whether to sue in the hands of the attorney general.
"For 90 years in this state, consistently all the decisions of the Mississippi Supreme Court have held the attorney general has sole authority," Moore said in court.
Chief Justice Dan Lee asked Moore if he sought the governor's permission to file the lawsuit.
"Neither sought, your honor, nor needed his permission," Moore replied.
Wayne Drinkwater, a Jackson lawyer representing Fordice, claimed the attorney general was trying to "usurp the authority the legislature has placed in the governor."
The issue is purely a matter of authority, Drinkwater maintained, not whether the lawsuit against the tobacco industry was good or bad public policy.
Moore filed the original lawsuit in Jackson County Chancery Court.
Six members of the state's nine-member supreme court heard arguments in the case.
